titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Dined at the Minister Struensee’s, with Marshall Möllendorf, Prince Repnin and a Company of 20 persons. The conversation was much upon military subjects. There was rather a studied than a natural cordiality between the principal. They talked a great deal, Prince Repnin especially—not a little, for the sake of talking— A curious discussion was started, upon the difference which there would be in the art of War, if armies required no provisions— The Prince thought light horse preferable to heavy cavalry— Möllendorf did not take much part in this conversation but drank his champaign.— Walk in the Evening, and at the Casino— Young Ladies to see Mrs: A— Bell Brown at supper— Night very warm.

2. Purchased a pair of carriage horses this morning for 30 Frederic d’ors, or about 25 Guineas.— Weather extremely warm untill a thunder shower in the afternoon— Ride round the park with Mrs: A. and Evening at home.

3. Dined at Marshall Möllendorf’s with Prince Repnin, and a company of about 30 persons. Sat next to the Marquis de Musquiz and the Count de Bernstorff, a son of the late celebrated Danish Minister. Dinner excessively long. We did not rise from table till near 6 o’clock— Found Mlle: Neale, on my return home. Evening at the Casino; reading the french, English and Hamburg papers.

4. Letters from Mr: Murray, and Mr: Pitcairn: answered the last.— Walk in the Park. Wrote to the Secy: of State. Evening at Princess Henry’s. Mrs: A. stayed only a few minutes.— Reversi with Madame de Haaren, Madame Parella, and M. Caillard.

5. Letter to Mr: Murray. Various little occurrences employed the remainder of the forenoon. After dinner visits from M. & Madame Parella, Miss Brown’s and Mlle: Neale.— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s at Belle-vue. Whist with Madame de Castel and two officers. The Prince has been very ill, and but recently recovered. The company not large.
6. Letter to W. Cranch— Walk in the Park before dinner.— Towards Evening at the Casino— French papers very abusive.— My German studies consume much of my time.
7. Mrs A had visits this afternoon from Mrs: Brown, and her daughters and from Miss Estoff—My brother at a ball: given by Mr. Cohen— Letter from Mr. Murray.— Weather extremely warm.

8. Wrote to Mr: Murray— Warm walk in the park. Finished reading Archenholz’s history of the 7 years War. The writer is a Prussian, and Frederic is always his hero.— Ride with Mrs: A. in the Evening, towards Potsdam.— Weather continues fine, and cooled in the Evening.

9. English newspapers.— Went to the play this Evening, with Mrs: A.— It was a Comedy in five Acts entitled “a Journey to town.” I could not fully understand either the plot or the dialogue; but a considerable part of it. The performers speak very low and very rapidly, imitating as much as possible the tone of private conversation. The house thin— After the play we rode in the park and walked home.

10. Letter from Mr: Murray, and one from Ratisbonne.— Sunday morning occupation. Walk into the Park. Evening at the Minister Heinitz’s, where the Princess Henry had made a party.— Whist with Madame de Castell, Count Wartensleben, and M. de Grovestein, a young dutchman, lately arrived here— My brother dined at Charlottenburg.

11. Letters again this morning from Philadelphia; up to the 13th: of April— At the Casino before dinner. In the Evening at Princess Henry’s; where my brother was presented.— We did not stay to cards. Ride with Mrs: A. in the park.—

12.— Have at length a bookcase.— Writing— Visited this afternoon our neighbour Count Golowkin; he lives directly under us.— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s at Bellevue.— The Prince conversed with me some time, upon the subject of our Constitution, and a comparison of it with that of France.— Reversi, with Madame Haaren, Madame Parella, and a Prussian Officer;—we stayed to supper— Mr: Helbig told me he was in correspondence with Archenholz, and recommended to me the perusal of an Account of Potemkin in the Minerva.— I have finished the appendages to his story of the 7 years war, and this morning began upon Gessner’s Death of Abel, of which I read the first book.

13. Being late, last Evening from Prince Ferdinand’s, was this morning later than usual up.— Walk in the morning of course short.— Evening at Madame de Saldern’s— Whist with her, with Count Wartensleben and M. de Caström Secretary to the Swedish legation— We went late—
14. Walk in the park.— At the Casino— Afternoon at the play— A Comedy of Kotzebue, called “the writing desk, or the dangers of youth[”]— Ride afterwards in the Park.

15. Visit this afternoon to the Marquise Parella, who was engaged and could not see us: to Madame Hagen whom we saw— Found there the Baron de Redern— Evening at the Minister Heinitz’s party— Whist with the Princess de Sacken, Madame de Pritwitz, and Baron Hagen.— Conversation with M. Caillard.— Miss Heinitz played on the piano forte, and the Countess Goltz sang.
16. Writing the forenoon, and began the draught of a Treaty.— Visit this afternoon from our neighbours Count & Countess Golowkin, their daughter, and Miss Fagel— At the Casino, in the Evening.

17. Mrs: A. unwell again— Morning employed as usual on this day.— Our neighbours went at 5. to Freyerwalde, a bathing place 6 German miles distant.— We went this afternoon to Doctor Brown’s at Charlottenburg. Saw there Miss Brühl and Baron Alvensleben— Home between 9 and 10.
18. Mrs: Adams extremely ill; all the morning, and again at night. Much alarmed for her.— Passed the day in an usual manner— Evening an hour at the Casino.— Received Letters from America.

19. Mrs: A. still unwell, though somewhat better than yesterday.— This morning finished Gessner’s Death of Abel; it seems to be meant as a sequel to the Paradise Lost— It may be called a pretty thing, but it is unfortunate in calling Milton’s poem so frequently to the mind— The descriptions of rural scenery are beautiful, for the author was more Painter, than Poet— The sentiments good, but too uniformly consisting of tenderness and affliction— Too soft and tearful. The characters of Adam and Eve closely imitated from Milton— Of Cain and Abel original, and well contrasted— Of their wives Mehala and Thirza not discriminated enough— The celestials are messengers, without distinctive marks, and Anamelech, the fallen spirit who prompts the atrocious deed, a pigmy devil indeed compared with Milton’s rebel angels.— Besides which he meets with no punishment for his infernal project, in which he is completely successful and from which he issues triumphant.— Evening an hour at what they call a Picnic—a company meet at a public house in the park, take tea in the open air under a sort of bower in the garden. Each guest pays 18 gr: for his fare; though invited by a Gentleman and Lady, who undertake to receive the other company as host and hostess. A number of them take this office by turns. This evening it was Count Zinzendorf and the Countess de Castell— Returned home very early.
20. Unquiet night.— This morning began Gessner’s “first mariner.” But I grow negligent about my German. Reading Mr: Monroe’s book against the American Government— At the Casino in the Evening.
21. Late morning. Wrote all the forenoon. At the Casino— Talleyrand’s observations upon the dispatches of the American Envoys.— Letter from Pitcairn promising dispatches from America.

22. Writing to my mother.— Received a large bundle of dispatches, pamphlets and newspapers from America.— Walk towards evening, having no time for it before dinner.— My accounts very different from those announced in the french papers.

23. Continued to be busily engaged in writing, almost the whole day. Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s at Bellevue.— Had considerable conversation with him, upon various subjects.— Whist with Made: Heinitz, Mlle. de Hagen, and Count Neale— Stayed to supper.
24. Mrs: Adams very ill all night and the whole of this day. Engaged as usual in the forenoon. Walk in the park. In the Evening spent an hour at the Casino.— Reading my American publications.

25. Mrs: A. continues quite ill, and this Evening was so very violently.— Letter to Secy: of State— Evening at Princess Henry’s. the Princess Louis, & Princess of Orange there, and the hereditary Prince and Princess of Brunswick, probably here to attend the ceremony of the homage, which is for the 6th: of next month.— Casino, with Made: de Blumenthal, Mlle: Heinitz, and another young Lady, a stranger.

26. Mrs: A. rather better, but still very unwell.— After finishing Gessner’s “first mariner,” began his Daphnis— Have also been reading Monroe’s book, and the observations of Scipio, with sundry other American pamphlets.— An hour this Evening at the Casino.

27. I pass more time in my own study, than I was able to before we came into this house.— Of course can both read and write more— But fail in the necessary exercise.— My walk this day very short.— At the Casino, in the Evening. Read Mr: Harper’s speech on the foreign intercourse bill.

28. Finished Gessner’s Daphnis. Took at length a long walk, in the park.— Began again after dinner to read in Mirabeau’s Monarchie Prussienne, which I have for a long time, laid aside.— Letters from America— From Mrs: Johnson, & Nancy to my wife— My letter of 11. October was offensive and painful.

29. Continue to read Gessner— At the play.— Raoul de Creque, in German.— Walk afterwards under the Linden— Met and walked with Messrs: Maisonneuve, Helbig, Bressac, Anadia, Knoblauch and lastly Musquiz—considerable conversation with the last.

30. Not attentive sufficiently to the proper business before me. Making out a cypher.— Walk towards Evening— Looked at the preparations making opposite the palace for the homage.— In the Park— At Casino.

Day. Rise at 7. Read German till 9. Breakfast.— Write, and attend my study till 2. Walk—dine— Again in my study and read till 7.— Walk or pass a couple of hours in company.— Sup.— Bed between 10 and 11.
